paragraphs.text: In the world of Machine Learning, solving an OCR problem is a classification problem. We build up a set of trained data, for example the digits from the image processing, classify them as something, and then use that data to match any new images. Once I got the basic image isolation working, I created a script that could loop over a folder of images, run the digit isolation code, and then save the cropped digits into a new folder for me to review. After that ran, I’d have a folder of untrained digits that I could then use to train a system.
paragraphs.name: 38e3

paragraphs.text: That's great! Crowdsourcing and Computer Vision together on apps can make some great impact. I've done an app for face recognition using OpenCV and iOS and it's amazingly cool also, i will write about it soon.
paragraphs.name: b247

980b66a3d399.title: Why don’t use tesseract ocr for this task?

paragraphs.text: Why don’t use tesseract ocr for this task?

1c9d74a40754.title: My initial plan was to use tesseract for this, but in my simple tests I wasn’t getting good results…

paragraphs.text: My initial plan was to use tesseract for this, but in my simple tests I wasn’t getting good results. I bet if I spent more time with it, it may have been an option, but since I already brought OpenCV in as a library for the image processing and it had the tools to do the OCR portion, I preferred to just use that and not bring in another dependency.
paragraphs.name: ed4c

27537c05ba7c.title: This is really an impressive endeavor you undertook Kaz.

paragraphs.text: This is really an impressive endeavor you undertook Kaz. Sounds like a bit of human learning in addition to machine learning took place! I often take image capture and analysis for granted, not realizing how much goes into it. This process will no doubt pay dividends to you beyond FuelMate. Kudos on working through this challenge.
paragraphs.name: 2c63
